choices.text: Give 300 mcg with 72 hr of delivery irrespective of baby blood group
No need for further dose of anti D
Give 300 mcg within 72 hrs of delivery if baby blood group is positive
Give another dose in next pregnancy

questions.text: A Rh negative woman has received anti D 28 weeks. What would be done for now
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Give 300 mcg within 72 hrs of delivery if baby blood group is positive
In Rh-negative pregnant women, there is a risk of Rh alloimmunization if the fetus is Rh-positive. To prevent this, anti-D immunoglobulin is administered. A routine 300 mcg dose is given at 28 weeks of gestation as antenatal prophylaxis. However, if the newborn is Rh-positive, another 300 mcg dose must be given within 72 hours postpartum. This prevents maternal sensitization from any fetomaternal hemorrhage occurring during delivery. If the baby is Rh-negative, no further anti-D is needed after birth.

questions.text: True about the image shown above
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Seen between 10-14 weeks
The ultrasound image shows the T-sign, which is indicative of monochorionic diamniotic (MCDA) twin pregnancy. In early pregnancy (between 10–14 weeks), a chorionicity scan is done to determine whether twins share a placenta (monochorionic) or have separate placentas (dichorionic). In a T-sign, the thin membrane separating the amniotic sacs meets the placenta at a 90° angle, forming a T shape, unlike the lambda or twin peak sign seen in dichorionic twins. Detecting this early helps in anticipating complications and planning closer surveillance.

questions.text: A primi has sudden onset of vaginal discharge at 32 weeks. On P/an exam no contractions and FHR is normal. What is next step
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Perform p/s exam
A sudden onset of vaginal discharge at 32 weeks in a primigravida, even without contractions and with a normal fetal heart rate (FHR), raises concern for premature rupture of membranes (PROM). A speculum (P/S) exam is the most appropriate next step because it allows for direct visualization of the cervix and vaginal vault. During this exam, the clinician can confirm if amniotic fluid is leaking (e.g., pooling in the posterior fornix, positive nitrazine test, or ferning test). It's a non-invasive way to diagnose PROM without increasing the risk of infection. If PROM is confirmed, further management would then be guided by the gestational age and clinical situation.

choices.text: Up to 50% patients May have pre-eclampsia
Moct commonly sen in third trimester

questions.text: Which if the following is not associated with acute fatty liver of pregnancy
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Associated with maternal LCHAD
Acute Fatty Liver of Pregnancy (AFLP) is a rare but severe obstetric complication. It is characterized by microvesicular fatty infiltration of hepatocytes. AFLP is not primarily associated with maternal LCHAD (Long-Chain 3-Hydroxyacyl-CoA Dehydrogenase) deficiency. Instead, AFLP is strongly linked to a fetal deficiency in LCHAD. When the fetus has an LCHAD deficiency, it cannot properly metabolize long-chain fatty acids. These unmetabolized fatty acid intermediates then cross the placenta into the maternal circulation, overwhelming the mother's mitochondrial β-oxidation system and leading to liver dysfunction and the characteristic fatty infiltration seen in AFLP.

questions.text: Not true about partial mole
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Easily diagnosed on usg
Partial hydatidiform moles are often challenging to diagnose definitively on ultrasound (USG). Their sonographic appearance can be highly variable and often overlaps with that of a miscarriage, blighted ovum, or even a normal pregnancy with coexisting pathology. While some features like a thickened, hydropic placenta and fetal parts with growth restriction can suggest a partial mole, these findings are not always clear or universally present. Definitive diagnosis usually requires histopathological examination of the evacuated tissue, looking for characteristic features like edematous villi with trophoblastic proliferation and fetal parts.

questions.text: Which will be best for pregnancy dating
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

CRL at 7-9 weeks
Crown-Rump Length (CRL) measurements taken between 7 and 9 weeks of gestation provide the most accurate estimation of gestational age and are considered the gold standard for pregnancy dating. During this early period, fetal growth is highly consistent and less influenced by genetic or environmental factors. The CRL measurement directly reflects the embryo's linear growth, and variations in growth are minimal, leading to a very narrow margin of error (typically ± 3-5 days). This allows for precise determination of the estimated due date.

questions.text: A woman was presented with APH, she was taken up for emergency CS and there is extensive bleeding and hysterectomy was done. Image is shown what is the diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Placenta accreta spectrum 
The image and scenario are classic for Placenta Accreta Spectrum (PAS) disorder. This condition involves abnormal adherence of the placenta to the myometrium due to partial or complete absence of the decidua basalis. It often presents with antepartum hemorrhage (APH) and massive intraoperative bleeding during cesarean section when attempts are made to remove the placenta. The uterus in the image shows a densely adherent placenta with disruption of the uterine wall and heavy bleeding, necessitating an emergency peripartum hysterectomy, which is the standard treatment in cases where the placenta cannot be separated safely. Risk factors include previous cesarean sections, placenta previa, and uterine surgery.

questions.text: Which is not a sign of MgSO4 toxicity
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Oliguria
Oliguria (decreased urine output) is not a direct sign of magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) toxicity itself. Instead, oliguria can contribute to magnesium sulfate toxicity. Magnesium is primarily excreted by the kidneys. If a patient becomes oliguric due to conditions like severe pre-eclampsia, dehydration, or acute kidney injury, the magnesium administered for seizure prophylaxis or treatment can accumulate in the body to toxic levels because it's not being cleared adequately. Therefore, oliguria is a risk factor for developing MgSO4 toxicity, not a symptom of it. Monitoring urine output is crucial when administering MgSO4 to ensure adequate renal excretion.

questions.text:
Not a component of BPP 

1. NST

2. Station

3. Fetal Tone

4. DFMC
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

2&4
The Biophysical Profile (BPP) is a comprehensive antepartum test used to assess fetal well-being. It typically involves five components, four assessed by ultrasound and one by external fetal monitoring. The standard components of a BPP are:
Non-stress test (NST): This assesses fetal heart rate reactivity.
Fetal breathing movements: Observed by ultrasound.
Fetal body movements: Observed by ultrasound.
Fetal tone: Assessed by observing limb flexion and extension (ultrasound).
Amniotic fluid volume (AFV): Measured by ultrasound (e.g., amniotic fluid index or deepest vertical pocket).
2. Station: This refers to the fetal station, which describes the descent of the presenting part of the fetus (usually the head) in relation to the maternal ischial spines. It is a measurement used during labor to assess progress but is not part of the antepartum BPP for fetal well-being assessment.
4. DFMC (Daily Fetal Movement Count): Also known as "kick counts," DFMC is a method where pregnant individuals manually count fetal movements over a specified period. It is an important and simple way for expectant mothers to monitor fetal well-being at home but is a separate assessment and not a component directly performed by the clinician as part of a formal BPP.

choices.text: Beta subunit used for preg test
It is first stimulus for release of testosterone from fetal testes

questions.text: Not true about hcg
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Steroid hormone
Human Chorionic Gonadotropin (hCG) is not a steroid hormone. It is a glycoprotein hormone. Glycoprotein hormones are composed of protein chains with attached carbohydrate moieties. hCG is structurally similar to luteinizing hormone (LH), follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), and thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), all of which are also glycoprotein hormones. Steroid hormones, such as estrogen and progesterone, are derived from cholesterol and have a distinct chemical structure.

choices.text: Oral iron plus FA plus iron sucrose
Iron sucrose iv when patient is resistant to oral iron

questions.text: Patient is 30 weeks pregnant and her Hb level is 8gm % What is management
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 Iron sucrose iv when patient is resistant to oral iron
In a 30-week pregnant woman with hemoglobin (Hb) of 8 g/dL, the anemia is classified as moderate. The first-line treatment in moderate anemia during pregnancy is usually oral iron therapy along with folic acid (FA). However, in cases where the patient is intolerant or unresponsive to oral iron (e.g., due to gastrointestinal side effects or poor absorption), the next step is to initiate parenteral iron therapy, most commonly iron sucrose IV. This bypasses the gastrointestinal tract and ensures faster replenishment of iron stores, which is important as the patient is already in the third trimester where time for hematologic correction is limited.

questions.text: Indication for induction of labour
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)


Preeclampsia at term
Preeclampsia at term is a common and strong indication for induction of labor. Preeclampsia is a multisystem disorder characterized by new-onset hypertension and proteinuria after 20 weeks of gestation. At term, the risks associated with continuing the pregnancy for both the mother (e.g., progression to severe preeclampsia, eclampsia, HELLP syndrome, stroke) and the fetus (e.g., placental insufficiency, growth restriction, stillbirth) often outweigh the risks of induction. Inducing labor allows for the delivery of the placenta, which is the definitive treatment for preeclampsia.

choices.text: There is absent beat to beat variability

questions.text: What is true about the graph shown
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

It is NST
The image shows a fetal heart rate tracing, which is part of the Non-Stress Test (NST). An NST is a non-invasive antepartum test that monitors fetal heart rate (FHR) in response to fetal movements, typically performed after 28 weeks in high-risk pregnancies or for routine monitoring. The graph displays only the FHR tracing, without uterine contraction data, which is characteristic of an NST. A normal NST shows baseline heart rate, variability, and reactive accelerations, helping assess fetal well-being.

choices.text: Uterine artery Doppler – screening for preeclampsia

questions.text: Which is not correctly matched
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Cordocentesis – screening for fetal anaemia 
Cordocentesis, also known as Percutaneous Umbilical Blood Sampling (PUBS), is an invasive diagnostic test used to obtain fetal blood directly from the umbilical vein, usually after 20 weeks of gestation. While it can be used to diagnose and treat fetal anemia (especially in cases like Rh isoimmunization or Parvovirus B19 infection), it is not used for routine screening. Screening for fetal anemia is non-invasive, typically done via Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA) Doppler studies. Hence, cordocentesis is a diagnostic and therapeutic procedure, not a screening test, making this the incorrect match.

questions.text:
Primi presents with headache and blurring of vision at 32 weeks. Her BP is 160/106 fundal height is 32 and FHR is 130. Which is included in her management 

1. Labetalol

2. MgSO4

3. Steroid 

4. Induction of labour
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

1, 2, 4
The clinical scenario describes a primigravida at 32 weeks gestation with severe hypertension (BP 160/106 mmHg) and symptoms like headache and blurring of vision, which are signs of severe preeclampsia. The management of such a case includes:
• Labetalol (1): This is a first-line antihypertensive used to lower severe blood pressure and prevent complications like stroke or placental abruption.
• Magnesium sulfate (2): This is administered for seizure prophylaxis, as she is at high risk of progressing to eclampsia.
• Induction of labour (4): Once maternal condition is stabilized, delivery is the definitive treatment. At 32 weeks, if the maternal condition is worsening, early delivery is often indicated, even if preterm.

questions.text:
Features of abruption are 

1. Pain 

2. Uterine tenderness 

3. Warning haemorrhage

4. Increase in uterine size
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

1, 2, 4
Placental abruption is the premature separation of a normally implanted placenta before delivery, a serious obstetric emergency. Classic features include:
Pain (1): Abruption typically presents with sudden, intense, continuous abdominal pain, which distinguishes it from placenta previa (which is usually painless).
Uterine tenderness (2): The uterus becomes tense and tender to palpation, due to concealed or revealed bleeding between the placenta and uterine wall.
Increase in uterine size (4): In concealed type abruption, bleeding accumulates inside the uterus, leading to an enlarged, tense uterus (sometimes referred to as a "woody hard" uterus).

questions.text: Answer this with respect to image shared below. What is not a finding in the woman with amenorrhea and positive UPT and the Usg image shown below
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Fundal height less than POG
The ultrasound image shows a snowstorm appearance — a classic finding in a complete molar pregnancy (hydatidiform mole). In such cases, the uterine size (fundal height) is usually larger than expected for period of gestation (POG) due to trophoblastic overgrowth and absence of a fetus. Hence, fundal height less than POG is not a feature of molar pregnancy, making it the correct answer to the question asking what is not found.

questions.text: A woman is pregnant with twins and is 32 weeks pregnant. She has had one male baby and one still birth at term what is her GPA status
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

G3P2
Gravida (G) refers to the total number of times a woman has been pregnant, regardless of the outcome.
Para (P) refers to the number of pregnancies reaching viability (typically ≥20–24 weeks), regardless of whether the baby was born alive or stillborn. Twin pregnancies count as one parity because it's based on pregnancies, not number of babies.
The woman is currently pregnant with twins this is her third pregnancy G3.
One previous live male baby (counts as 1 parity),
One stillbirth at term (stillborn but beyond viability also counts as 1 parity),
So, two previous pregnancies reached viability P2.

questions.text: All are physiological auscultatory findings in pregnancy except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Wide split S2
During pregnancy, cardiovascular adaptations occur due to increased blood volume, cardiac output, and hormonal changes. However, a wide split of the second heart sound (S2) is not considered a physiological finding in pregnancy. Instead, a wide split S2 may suggest an underlying cardiac pathology, such as pulmonary hypertension, right bundle branch block, or atrial septal defect (ASD). It is abnormal and warrants further evaluation if heard.

choices.text: LMP Calculated from last day of LMP
Prolactin is highest in third trimester
Placenta takes over function of corpus luteum at 8 weeks

questions.text: Not true is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

LMP calculated from last day of LMP
This statement is not true. The Last Menstrual Period (LMP) is universally calculated from the first day of the last menstrual period, not the last day. This is the standard method used to estimate gestational age and calculate the estimated date of delivery (EDD) using Naegele's rule (LMP + 9 months + 7 days). Counting from the last day of LMP would lead to an incorrect and shorter gestational age estimation.

questions.text: Which teratogen is not correctly matched to the usg finding in fetus
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Valproate – microtia
This statement is not correctly matched. While valproate (valproic acid) is a known teratogen, its characteristic fetal malformation is neural tube defects, particularly spina bifida. Other reported anomalies with valproate exposure include craniofacial defects, limb defects, and cardiovascular anomalies, but microtia (underdevelopment of the ear) is not the most classically associated or prominent ultrasound finding linked directly to valproate. Microtia is more commonly associated with other teratogens or genetic syndromes.

questions.text: Which is most common cause of first trimester recurrent pregnancy loss
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Chromosomal abnormalities
Chromosomal abnormalities are, by far, the most common cause of first-trimester recurrent pregnancy loss (RPL). Approximately 50-70% of sporadic (single) first-trimester miscarriages are due to chromosomal aneuploidies (e.g., trisomies, monosomies, polyploidy). While the incidence in recurrent losses might be slightly lower than sporadic losses, it still remains the leading cause. These abnormalities are typically random errors during gamete formation or early embryonic development and are often incompatible with sustained fetal development. Karyotyping of products of conception (POC) from miscarriages frequently reveals these genetic errors.

questions.text: A woman with history of uterine cramping and bleeding at 10 weeks presents to emergency with history of passage of tissue. On examination the os is open and there is profuse bleeding. What is the likely diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Incomplete abortion
The clinical presentation of a woman at 10 weeks gestation with uterine cramping, bleeding, passage of tissue, and an open cervical os with profuse bleeding is most consistent with an incomplete abortion. In incomplete abortion, some products of conception have been expelled, but some remain in the uterus, leading to continued bleeding and an open cervix. It is a medical emergency requiring prompt management to prevent hemorrhagic shock and infection, often with uterine evacuation.

questions.text: A lady presents at 12 weeks with missed abortion. She had a previous loss also at 10 weeks. She gives history of one still birth due to preterm delivery to severe preeclampsia. What is likely etiology
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

APLA
The most likely etiology in this case is Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome (APLA), an acquired thrombophilia that causes recurrent pregnancy losses, especially in the first trimester, and is also linked to late pregnancy complications such as severe preeclampsia, intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR), and stillbirths. The history of repeated early losses (10 and 12 weeks) along with a previous stillbirth due to severe preeclampsia strongly suggests APLA syndrome. APLA leads to thrombosis of placental vessels, impairing placental function and causing fetal demise or adverse outcomes.

questions.text: The best screening test for Down syndrome
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Cell free fetal DNA test
The Cell-free fetal DNA (cfDNA) test, also known as non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT), is the most sensitive and specific screening test for Down syndrome (Trisomy 21). It analyzes fetal DNA fragments in maternal blood as early as 10 weeks gestation and has a detection rate >99% with a very low false-positive rate. It is especially useful in high-risk pregnancies (advanced maternal age, prior child with chromosomal abnormality, abnormal ultrasound findings). While it is a screening test (not diagnostic), it is the most accurate among all screening options, making it the best.

questions.text: Lady at 30 weeks presents with uterine contractions and cervical dilatation of 2 cm. All will be done except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Cerclage
The patient presents at 30 weeks with uterine contractions and cervical dilation of 2 cm. This clinical picture is indicative of preterm labor. In managing preterm labor, the primary goals are to inhibit contractions (tocolysis), promote fetal lung maturity, and provide neuroprotection if indicated. Cerclage, on the other hand, is a surgical procedure to reinforce an incompetent cervix and is performed before significant cervical changes or labor onset, typically in the first or early second trimester (usually before 24 weeks). Once a woman is in active preterm labor with cervical changes like 2 cm dilation, a cerclage is contraindicated because it can rupture the membranes, cause infection, or damage the cervix.

questions.text: Lady with history of preterm labour in her previous pregnancy now presents at 18 weeks with cervical length of 20mm which is the most appropriate management for this
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Cerclage with progesterone 
In a woman with a history of spontaneous preterm labor and a short cervical length (<25 mm) identified on ultrasound at 18 weeks, the most appropriate management is cerclage placement along with progesterone therapy. This scenario fits the criteria for history-indicated cerclage with ultrasound reinforcement. Cervical length of 20 mm at 18 weeks is considered abnormally short, increasing the risk of preterm birth. The combination of cerclage and progesterone provides the maximum benefit in preventing recurrence of preterm labor in high-risk women.

questions.text: A lady after evacuation for molar presents with cannon ball appearance of chest X ray. What is the likely stage of GTN
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Stage 3
The presence of cannon ball lesions on chest X-ray is highly suggestive of pulmonary metastases, which are classically seen in gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN) following a molar pregnancy. According to the FIGO staging system, Stage 3 GTN is defined as disease that has spread to the lungs (with or without genital tract involvement), but no other distant metastases

questions.text: Amniotic fluid will be increased in all except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Posterior urethral valve in fetus
Posterior urethral valve (PUV) is a condition in male fetuses where there is an obstruction to urinary outflow, leading to reduced fetal urine production. Since fetal urine is the primary source of amniotic fluid in the second and third trimesters, any obstruction results in oligohydramnios (reduced amniotic fluid) amniotic fluid will be decreased, not increased, in PUV,

choices.text: Modified BPP includes NST and Amniotic fluid volume
SDP is used for estimation of amniotic fluid in twin pregnancy

questions.text: Which is not correct statement with respect to amniotic fluid estimation
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 SDP less than 5 is oligohydramnios 
This statement is not correct. The Single Deepest Pocket (SDP), also known as the Deepest Vertical Pocket (DVP), is a method used to estimate amniotic fluid volume. When using SDP, a value of less than 2 cm (or 20 mm) is considered oligohydramnios. A value of 5 cm or less (as stated in the option) would typically still be within the normal or low-normal range depending on the specific criteria used, but not necessarily oligohydramnios. Oligohydramnios by SDP is generally defined as ≤ 2 cm, while polyhydramnios is ≥ 8 cm.

questions.text: Primigravida in labour at 7 cm dilatation and vertex at 0 station presents with profuse bleeding and severe fetal bradycardia after rupture of membranes. On examination uterus is term size non tender. What could be likely cause
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 Vasa previa
Vasa previa occurs when fetal blood vessels traverse the membranes in the lower uterine segment, unprotected by placenta or cord, and cross the cervical os. These vessels are vulnerable to rupture, especially after rupture of membranes. The hallmark features include:
Sudden painless bleeding
Fetal bradycardia or death (due to rapid fetal blood loss)
Non-tender uterus
Often occurs in a previously normal labour

questions.text: Lady with Rh negative pregnancy presents at 28 weeks with ict tiger 1:8 what is the next step in her management
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 Repeat after 4 weeks
Rh-negative pregnant woman at 28 weeks with an indirect Coombs test (ICT) titer of 1:8. An ICT titer of 1:8 is considered a "critical titer" or low-positive, meaning that Rh alloimmunization has occurred, but it is not yet at a level typically associated with severe fetal anemia or hydrops. The standard management for a low-positive or non-rising critical titer is to repeat the ICT titer every 2-4 weeks to monitor for any significant increase. A rising titer (e.g., to 1:16 or higher, depending on local guidelines) would then warrant more aggressive fetal surveillance, such as Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA) Doppler studies. At 1:8, the risk of severe fetal anemia requiring intervention is low, and the immediate next step is continued surveillance.

questions.text: Primi at 42 weeks coms for IOL her cervix is long, closed and posterior. The FHR is 140s. PGE2 gel is put P/v. 1hr later, the patient is having contractions lasting longer than 2 min. The FHR falls to 70s. Which is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Administer terbutaline
The patient is experiencing uterine hyperstimulation (tachysystole) defined as contractions lasting longer than 2 minutes or more than 5 contractions in 10 minutes which is a complication of prostaglandin use (PGE₂) for cervical ripening. This excessive uterine activity has led to fetal bradycardia (FHR in 70s) due to uteroplacental insufficiency. The immediate management is to reduce uterine tone to restore fetal oxygenation. Terbutaline, a beta-2 agonist, is a tocolytic that relaxes the uterus and is the first-line drug for reversing hyperstimulation.

questions.text: The above fetal complication shown is not seen with which of the following
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

HIV
The image shows hydrops fetalis, a condition characterized by abnormal accumulation of fluid in two or more fetal compartments, such as skin edema, pleural effusion, pericardial effusion, or ascites. This condition can result from immune causes (e.g., Rh incompatibility) or non-immune causes such as congenital infections or fetal anemia. HIV infection, however, is not associated with hydrops fetalis

questions.text: The above shown twin pregnancy complication is seen in which type of twin
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

MCDA
The image depicts Twin-Twin Transfusion Syndrome (TTTS), a serious complication of monochorionic diamniotic (MCDA) twin pregnancies. In MCDA twins, both fetuses share a single placenta (monochorionic) but have separate amniotic sacs (diamniotic). Due to vascular anastomoses in the shared placenta, blood can flow disproportionately between the twins. One twin (the donor) becomes hypovolemic and growth-restricted, while the other (the recipient) becomes hypervolemic and may develop polyhydramnios and heart failure. Therefore, TTTS occurs exclusively in MCDA pregnancies

questions.text: How will you deliver these babies
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

CS
A twin pregnancy in which the first twin (Twin A) is in breech presentation, while the second twin (Twin B) is in cephalic presentation. In obstetric practice, cesarean section (CS) is recommended when the first twin is not in cephalic presentation, especially in primigravida. Vaginal delivery with a breech first twin increases the risk of birth trauma, cord prolapse, and complications in delivery of the second twin

questions.text: Maternal change not brought about by estrogen in pregnancy
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Stria gravidarum
Stria gravidarum, commonly known as stretch marks, are skin changes that occur in pregnancy due to the stretching of the dermis as the abdomen (and breasts, thighs, etc.) expands rapidly. While hormonal changes of pregnancy are believed to play a role in altering the connective tissue properties, the primary cause of striae gravidarum is mechanical stretching of the skin due to rapid weight gain and uterine enlargement, rather than a direct and specific effect of estrogen. While estrogen and other hormones like relaxin and corticosteroids do influence collagen and elastin, the direct, primary cause of the visible stretch marks is physical stretching.

choices.text: Indomethacin – premature closure of ductus arteriosus

questions.text: What is not matched correctly with their side effect
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Misoprostol – hypothermia
Misoprostol is a synthetic prostaglandin E1 (PGE1) analogue primarily used in obstetrics for cervical ripening, labor induction, and management of postpartum hemorrhage. While it has several side effects, fever and chills (pyrexia) are commonly reported, especially with higher doses. Hypothermia (abnormally low body temperature) is not a typical or expected side effect of misoprostol. In fact, its pyrogenic effect is a recognized side effect, often leading to a transient rise in body temperature.

choices.text: Resuscitation with fluid and wait and watch

questions.text: Lady with painless bleeding for 2 hr presents to emergency at 32 weeks. BP is 90/60 PR 120 and fetal heart sounds are not heard. Her previous Usg shows central placenta previa what is management
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 Em CS 
The patient presents with classic signs of placenta previa: painless vaginal bleeding, hypotension (BP 90/60), tachycardia (PR 120), and absent fetal heart sounds at 32 weeks gestation. Ultrasound already shows central placenta previa, which is a major degree placenta previa (covering the internal os). In placenta previa, the bleeding is maternal in origin and can be life-threatening. Even though the fetus is already demised, the mother is hemodynamically unstable, and vaginal delivery is contraindicated due to the placenta covering the os. Hence, immediate Cesarean section is needed to control bleeding and save the mother’s life.

questions.text: Which of these is not routinely for all pregnant women at first antenatal visit
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

TSH
Thyroid Stimulating Hormone (TSH) screening is not routinely performed for all pregnant women at their first antenatal visit in all guidelines worldwide. While some professional bodies (e.g., American Thyroid Association) recommend universal screening for thyroid dysfunction in pregnancy, others (e.g., American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists - ACOG) recommend targeted screening based on risk factors (e.g., history of thyroid disease, goiter, autoimmune disorders, type 1 diabetes).

questions.text: A lady with history of previous Spina bifida is given 4mg Folic acid up to what time period
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Till 12 weeks
For a woman with a history of a previous pregnancy affected by a neural tube defect (NTD) like spina bifida, the recommended dose of folic acid for prevention in subsequent pregnancies is a high dose, typically 4 mg (or 5 mg in some regions), starting at least one month before conception and continuing until 12 weeks of gestation. The neural tube closes between the 21st and 28th day after conception (i.e., by the end of the 6th week of pregnancy from LMP).

choices.text: Increased risk of other congenital anomalies
It is physiological till 24 weeks so no further evaluation needed

questions.text: A lady undergoing level 2 scan shows the above finding. Which is not true about the condition
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 It is physiological till 24 weeks so no further evaluation needed
The not true question. Physiological herniation of bowel into the base of the cord normally occurs up to 11–12 weeks of gestation. Beyond that, herniation is considered pathological, such as omphalocele. This condition requires further evaluation, including anomaly scan, karyotyping, and screening for associated anomalies. So, saying no further evaluation is needed till 24 weeks is false

questions.text: What is diagnosis in level 2 Usg and of a woman shown above
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Anencephaly
Anencephaly is diagnosed on Level 2 ultrasound by the absence of calvarium (skull vault) and cerebral hemispheres above the orbits. The exposed neural tissue degenerates, resulting in a frog-eye appearance in some views due to prominent orbits. It is uniformly lethal and easily detected in the second trimester.

questions.text: Which is preferred anaesthesia for CS in a pregnant woman with heart disease
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Epidural
In pregnant women with heart disease, epidural anesthesia is the preferred choice for cesarean section. This is because it provides a gradual and controlled onset of sympathetic blockade, avoiding the sudden hypotension associated with spinal anesthesia. Epidural anesthesia allows better hemodynamic stability, reducing the risk of sudden preload or afterload changes, which is critical in managing patients with compromised cardiac function. Additionally, epidural anesthesia provides excellent analgesia without the risks of general anesthesia in pregnant patients.

questions.text: All the following are done to prevent perineal tears during delivery except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Rapid extension of head

Rapid extension of the fetal head during delivery is not done to prevent perineal tears; in fact, it is a technique that would increase the risk of tears. A controlled, slow delivery of the fetal head, allowing for gradual stretching of the perineal tissues, is crucial for preventing tears. Rapid extension puts excessive and sudden strain on the perineum, making tears more likely. The goal is often to deliver the head slowly by "flexion," allowing the smallest diameter of the head to pass, and then to control extension.

questions.text: Not a component of bishops score
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 Type of pelvis
The Bishop score is a widely used scoring system to assess cervical ripeness and predict the likelihood of successful vaginal delivery following induction of labor. It evaluates the readiness of the cervix based on five components, each assigned a score of 0, 1, 2, or 3. The type of pelvis is not a component of the Bishop score. Pelvic type is a anatomical assessment of the maternal bony pelvis, which is assessed separately, and while it can influence the mode of delivery, it doesn't directly indicate cervical readiness for induction.
Cervical Effacement (or Length)
Cervical Dilation
Cervical Consistency (firmness)
Cervix Position
Fetal Station

questions.text: Not true about mediolateral episiotomy
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Cannot be extended 
A mediolateral episiotomy, by its very nature, is designed to be extendable laterally if a larger incision is needed to facilitate delivery or prevent a more severe tear. In fact, one of the theoretical advantages often cited for the mediolateral approach over a midline episiotomy is that it is less likely to extend directly into the anal sphincter or rectum, and if extension does occur, it can be extended further laterally.

questions.text: Which blood parameter does not increase in pregnancy
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Factor 11
During pregnancy, there is a complex interplay of hormonal and physiological changes that affect the hematological system, generally leading to a hypercoagulable state. While many clotting factors increase, Factor XI (Factor 11) is one of the few coagulation factors that typically does not significantly increase or may even slightly decrease in concentration during pregnancy. This is in contrast to most other factors (like Factors VII, VIII, X, XII, fibrinogen) which increase. The relative decrease or stability of Factor XI is a notable exception to the general procoagulant shift.

choices.text: Ask her to come for repeat Usg
Tell her she is not pregnant and test is false positive

questions.text: Lady presents with 5 weeks amenorrhea and spotting. Her UPT is positive and Usg shows no intrauterine pregnancy with normal adnexa. What should be done next
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Serial serum hcg
In a woman with 5 weeks of amenorrhea, a positive urine pregnancy test, and no intrauterine pregnancy visualized on ultrasound, the most appropriate next step is to measure serial serum β-hCG levels. This is essential to determine the viability and location of the pregnancy—whether it is a very early intrauterine pregnancy, a failing pregnancy, or an ectopic pregnancy. In early pregnancy, serum β-hCG levels should double approximately every 48–72 hours if the pregnancy is viable. Lack of appropriate rise or plateauing of hCG suggests non-viable or ectopic pregnancy.

questions.text: A lady comes at 8 weeks for her first ANC visit. All are advised for her except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

IFA tab
At the first antenatal (ANC) visit at 8 weeks, Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) tablets are not routinely started unless the pregnancy has reached 12 weeks gestation. According to standard guidelines (such as those followed in India and WHO), IFA supplementation (Iron 60 mg + Folic Acid 500 mcg daily) is recommended after the first trimester, starting from 12 weeks onwards to avoid early gastrointestinal side effects and because iron needs increase later in pregnancy.

questions.text: Medical outpatient abortion as per MTP act is allowed up to
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

9 weeks
As per the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act (amended in 2021), medical abortion in an outpatient setting (i.e. without surgical intervention or hospitalization) is allowed up to 9 weeks (63 days) of gestation. This includes the use of mifepristone followed by misoprostol, and can be administered safely without admission if the woman is stable and meets the inclusion criteria. Beyond 9 weeks, the risk of incomplete abortion and complications increases, and surgical methods or supervised care are preferred.

choices.text: Opinion of 2 RMP needed between 20-24 weeks
For gross anomaly MTP can be done beyond 24 week after board approval
For minor consent of guardian needed

questions.text: Not true according to MTp amendment act 2021
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Consent of husband needed
According to the MTP Amendment Act 2021, consent of the husband or partner is not required for performing a medical termination of pregnancy. The woman’s consent alone is sufficient, provided she is a major (≥18 years) and mentally sound. This reinforces a woman’s bodily autonomy and reproductive rights, allowing her to make independent decisions regarding pregnancy termination.

questions.text: All are indications are for surgical treatment of ectopic except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hcg value 3000
An hCG value of 3000 IU/L alone is not an absolute indication for surgical management of ectopic pregnancy. This level falls within the range where medical management (e.g., methotrexate) can still be considered, provided the patient is stable, sac size is small (<3.5–4 cm), there is no cardiac activity, and no rupture.

questions.text: Usg for a patient at 11 weeks shows the following measurement of 4 mm what should be done next
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
 CVS
The image shows increased nuchal translucency (NT), which is measured at 4 mm at 11 weeks of gestation. A nuchal translucency >3.5 mm is considered significantly increased and is associated with a high risk of chromosomal abnormalities, particularly Trisomy 21 (Down syndrome), Trisomy 18, 13, and Turner syndrome, as well as certain structural anomalies (like cardiac defects).
In this scenario, since the gestational age is 11 weeks, the next best step is to offer an invasive diagnostic test — specifically Chorionic Villus Sampling (CVS) — which can provide a definitive karyotype result early in pregnancy (between 11–13 weeks). This allows for timely decision-making regarding further management.

questions.text: A lady at 32 weeks presents with bleeding and pain with decreased fetal movements. In examination fundal height is 34 weeks and on exam cervix is closed. What is management
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 Immediate CS
The patient is at 32 weeks of gestation and presents with pain, bleeding, and decreased fetal movements. On examination, the fundal height is 34 weeks (suggesting concealed bleeding or uterine distension) and the cervix is closed. These are classic signs of placental abruption a potentially life-threatening condition for both mother and fetus. Decreased fetal movements indicate fetal compromise, and any delay in delivery can result in fetal demise or severe neonatal morbidity.

questions.text: Gestational diabetes can result in all the following complication except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Congenital anomalies
Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) typically develops after organogenesis is complete, usually diagnosed during the second or third trimester of pregnancy. As a result, GDM is not associated with congenital anomalies, which arise due to teratogenic influences during the first trimester. Instead, GDM is mainly linked to metabolic complications in the fetus and neonate, such as macrosomia, polyhydramnios, and delivery complications like shoulder dystocia.

questions.text: All the following are early interventions for a women having PPH after vaginal birth except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

B Lynch
The B-Lynch suture is a surgical intervention used to manage postpartum hemorrhage (PPH), but it is not an early step in the management of PPH after a vaginal birth. It is usually reserved for intractable bleeding during or after cesarean section when medical management has failed. In a woman who has delivered vaginally, the B-Lynch procedure requires laparotomy, which is invasive and not part of first-line interventions.

questions.text: All the following drugs are used in AMTSL except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Carboprost
Carboprost is not used in Active Management of Third Stage of Labour (AMTSL). It is a prostaglandin analog (PGF2α) primarily reserved for the treatment of postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) when initial uterotonics fail. Because of its side effect profile (notably bronchospasm and gastrointestinal discomfort), it is not included as a routine component of AMTSL.

questions.text: 30-year-old primigravida in labor with transverse lie. Treatment of choice is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

CS
In a 30-year-old primigravida in labor with transverse lie, the treatment of choice is cesarean section (CS). Transverse lie refers to a fetal position where the long axis of the fetus is perpendicular to the long axis of the uterus, making vaginal delivery impossible. In a primigravida who is already in labor, the uterus is contracting, and there is risk of cord prolapse, uterine rupture, or obstructed labor

choices.text: An be applied for fetal distress

questions.text: Not trye about above instrument is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Can be applied for CPD
Wrigley’s forceps cannot be used in cases of cephalopelvic disproportion (CPD) because it is too short to reach higher stations in the pelvis and does not provide enough traction for difficult deliveries. It is meant for use only when the fetal head is low and there is no disproportion. Using it in CPD could lead to complications or failed delivery.

choices.text: Both A and B are correct
Both A and B are incorrect

questions.text: Where is flexion point located
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Both A and B are correct
The flexion point is a crucial landmark used during operative vaginal deliveries (e.g., vacuum-assisted delivery). It is the optimal point on the fetal head where the cup should be placed to facilitate effective traction and promote proper flexion of the head during delivery. The flexion point is anatomically located:
3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle
6 cm posterior to the anterior fontanelle
These two measurements describe the same point on the sagittal suture of the fetal skull but from different reference points. Hence, both statements are accurate and describe the same anatomical landmark.

questions.text: Which of the following is contraindication for vacuum extraction
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Station O
Vacuum extraction is contraindicated when the fetal head is not engaged, such as in station 0. Station 0 means the presenting part of the fetus is at the level of the ischial spines, which implies that the head is not yet sufficiently descended for a safe vacuum-assisted delivery. Vacuum delivery requires the fetal head to be at low station (at least +2 or lower) and the cervix to be fully dilated, to avoid risks like failed extraction, scalp trauma, or intracranial hemorrhage.

questions.text: Lady with vertex presentation is in obstructed labour and FHR is absent. What is management
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

CS
In a woman with vertex presentation, obstructed labor, and absent fetal heart rate (FHR) (i.e., intrauterine fetal demise), cesarean section (CS) is still the preferred mode of delivery if the head is high or not accessible vaginally. This is because craniotomy or other destructive procedures require the fetal head to be low and accessible, and such skills are not routinely available in many modern obstetric setups. CS is also preferred to prevent maternal trauma, uterine rupture, or further complications, especially when the obstruction is high or the cervix is not fully dilated.

questions.text: Lady after delivery develops sudden onset of breathlessness and hypotension, she soon develops massive bleeding what is likely cause
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Amniotic fluid embolism 
Amniotic fluid embolism (AFE) is a rare but catastrophic obstetric emergency that typically presents suddenly during or shortly after delivery. It is characterized by acute onset of breathlessness, hypotension, hypoxia, seizures, and coagulopathy (often leading to massive postpartum hemorrhage). The pathophysiology involves amniotic fluid, fetal cells, or other debris entering the maternal circulation, triggering an anaphylactoid reaction rather than a true embolic phenomenon.
In this question, the woman develops sudden breathlessness, hypotension, followed by massive bleeding a classic triad for amniotic fluid embolism. The coagulopathy and DIC resulting from AFE can lead to uncontrollable hemorrhage

questions.text: What is next step in management
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Manual reposition
In cases of acute uterine inversion, the most critical and immediate step is to manually reposition the uterus back into its correct anatomical position. This procedure, often referred to as the Johnson maneuver, must be performed as quickly as possible at the bedside to stop the profuse bleeding and prevent hypovolemic shock. Delaying repositioning for procedures like shifting to the operation theatre or waiting for blood transfusions can lead to severe and potentially fatal complications. Oxytocin should only be administered after successful repositioning to help the uterus contract and prevent re-inversion.

questions.text: Which sign is shown
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Hegar
The image illustrates a bimanual pelvic examination where the fingers are palpating the lower uterine segment, or isthmus, between the firmer cervix and the fundus. This specific finding, characterized by a marked softening of the uterine isthmus, allowing the examining fingers to almost meet, is known as Hegar's sign. It is an early probable sign of pregnancy, typically detectable between 6 to 12 weeks of gestation, and is caused by the increased vascularity and hormonal changes occurring in early pregnancy.

questions.text: Which manoeuvre
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Burns Marshall
The image depicts the Burns Marshall maneuve, which is a technique used for the controlled delivery of the after-coming head in a breech presentation. In this maneuver, after the fetal body has delivered up to the neck, the baby's body is allowed to hang downwards for a short period to aid in head flexion and descent. Then, the baby's body is gently swept upwards in a wide arc over the mother's abdomen while applying gentle suprapubic pressure, facilitating the delivery of the fetal head in a flexed position. The illustrations clearly show this characteristic upward sweeping motion and support of the baby's body as the head emerges.

questions.text: The following position is likely seen with which type of maternal pelvis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Anthropoid
The image displays the fetal head engaged in the maternal pelvis in an occiput posterior (OP) position, where the longest diameter of the fetal head (anteroposterior) is aligned with the anteroposterior diameter of the maternal pelvic inlet. An anthropoid pelvis is characterized by an oval or elongated shape at the inlet, with the anteroposterior diameter being longer than the transverse diameter. This anatomical configuration of the anthropoid pelvis naturally favors the engagement and descent of the fetal head in either an occiput anterior (OA) or, as depicted in the image, an occiput posterior (OP) position, as the fetal head aligns with the longest available diameter of the pelvis.

questions.text: Primigravida with labour pain presents at 37 weeks. She is in labour for 10 hr and cervix is 4cm what is manaegement
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Wait and Watch
The patient is a primigravida at 37 weeks, in labor for 10 hours, and her cervix is 4 cm dilated. For a primigravida, the active phase of labor (where cervical dilation progresses more rapidly) typically begins around 6 cm dilation. At 4 cm, she is still in the latent phase of labor. The latent phase can be quite prolonged, especially in primigravidas, often lasting many hours without indicating abnormal labor progression. Given that she has only reached 4 cm after 10 hours, this is within the expected physiological range for the latent phase. The most appropriate management at this point is to continue to monitor her progress (wait and watch), provide supportive care, and allow labor to progress spontaneously without unnecessary intervention, assuming maternal and fetal conditions are reassuring.

questions.text: Fertilised ovum reaches uterine cavity by
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

4-5 days after fertilization
After fertilization occurs in the ampulla of the fallopian tube, the zygote undergoes a series of mitotic divisions (cleavage) as it travels towards the uterus. By approximately 4 to 5 days after fertilization, the developing embryo reaches the uterine cavity as a morula (a solid ball of cells) and then rapidly develops into a blastocyst. The blastocyst then floats freely in the uterine cavity for about 1-2 days before implantation begins. Therefore, the fertilized ovum, in its early developmental stages, arrives in the uterine cavity around 4-5 days post-fertilization.

questions.text: All hormones increase in pregnancy except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Free T3 T4
While total T3 and T4 levels increase significantly in pregnancy due to increased thyroid-binding globulin (TBG) (which binds to the hormones), the free (unbound) fractions of T3 and T4 generally remain within the non-pregnant reference range or show only a modest, transient increase early in pregnancy (due to hCG stimulation of the thyroid) before returning to baseline. The body tightly regulates the levels of metabolically active free hormones. Therefore, free T3 and T4 do not generally "increase" throughout pregnancy; rather, they are maintained within a relatively stable range.

questions.text: Lady undergoes induction of labour. 6 hrs later she is getting 4contractions in 10 min and she is fully dilated with head on the perineum and a caput is present, there is no moulding. FHR is dipping to 100bpm and what is next step in management
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Forceps deliver
The woman is fully dilated, has 4 contractions in 10 minutes, the fetal head is on the perineum, FHR is dropping to 100 bpm, and caput is present but no moulding—all suggesting that the second stage of labor is ongoing but the fetus is experiencing distress (FHR deceleration). Since the fetal head is very low (on the perineum), forceps-assisted vaginal delivery is the most appropriate immediate intervention to expedite birth and prevent further fetal compromise.
Forceps are often used in outlet or low forceps delivery when:
Cervix is fully dilated
Membranes are ruptured
Head is engaged and at +2 station or below
Fetal position is known
No cephalopelvic disproportion

questions.text: What is engaging diameter in a deflexed head
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Suboccipetofrontal
A deflexed head presentation (also known as military presentation or sinciput presentation) occurs when the fetal head is neither flexed nor extended. The fetal head presents with the occipitofrontal diameter as the engaging diameter. In this specific presentation, the part of the head that is just below the occiput (suboccipital region) and the frontal bone (forehead) become the presenting points for measurement, hence the diameter is called Suboccipitofrontal. This diameter measures approximately 10 cm and is larger than the suboccipitobregmatic diameter (which presents in a well-flexed head), making descent through the pelvis more challenging than with a well-flexed head.

choices.text: First phase is completed by 16 weeks
Endo vascular cells do the remodeling

questions.text: Not true about vascular remodeling in pregnancy
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

First phase is completed by 16 weeks
This statementis not true. The process of spiral artery remodeling in pregnancy is a crucial physiological adaptation that occurs in two phases. The first phase of remodeling, involving the decidual segments of the spiral arteries, is generally completed by 12 weeks of gestation. The second phase, which involves the myometrial segments of the spiral arteries, occurs between approximately 14 and 20-22 weeks of gestation.

choices.text: Stop warfarin and start unfractionated heparin
Stop warfarin, start LMWH and asprin

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 36 weeks of gestation with a prosthetic valve replacement for mitral stenosis is on warfarin therap. Her INR is 3. What is the appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Stop warfarin and start LMWH
In a pregnant woman at 36 weeks with a mechanical prosthetic valve on warfarin, the appropriate step is to stop warfarin and switch to low molecular weight heparin (LMWH). Warfarin crosses the placenta and poses a significant risk of fetal bleeding, particularly intracranial hemorrhage during late pregnancy and labor. After 36 weeks, the fetus is viable and labor can occur at any time, so anticoagulation needs to be managed safely to minimize maternal thrombotic risk while preventing fetal complications. LMWH does not cross the placenta and is considered safer during the peripartum period.
